page.title: 08Wingate - New Housing
page.content: When the colliery was first opened in Wingate, the{coal owners built {houses for the mineworkers. The{first}of these streets in Wingate was{called Sinkers Row,}long since demolished, these were{occupied {by the men who dug out the mine shaft. Many more streets were built when the mine was fully operational. Since the closing of the mine most of these streets have disappeared and the land reclaimed. Oddly the same land has tended not to be used for the building of new houses. Instead urbanisation has begun to encroach on the woodland on the edge of the village. Possibly the idea of people living 'in the country' appealed to the local planning department. This is particularly unusual as in Station Town, a sister village, the reverse has been the case.
